p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the 34th report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracey Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP
This committee is supported by staff of the Department of the House of Representatives

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 10 October and 6 November
1. The committee resolved to present the following 44 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 126 petitioners—requesting the release of an individual from immigration detention (EN6622)
From 3 petitioners—requesting the implementation of restrictions on social media for teenaged users (EN6623)
From 13 petitioners—regarding the definition of dependant as it relates to the Migration Act 1958 (EN6629)
From 144 petitioners—requesting a reduction in the costs and processing times for Parent visas (EN6630)
From 3 petitioners—requesting legislation to support renewable agriculture (EN6632)
From 4 petitioners—requesting that action be taken to address online radicalisation (EN6633)
From 19 petitioners—requesting a total ban on gambling advertising (EN6634)
From 2 petitioners—regarding violence within aged care facilities (EN6635)
From 5 petitioners—regarding the management of medications and pharmacy services in aged care (EN6637)
From 176 petitioners—requesting an inquiry into the strata management industry (EN6638)
From 1 petitioner—requesting that the Voluntary AI Safety Standard be strengthened (EN6639)
From 31 petitioners—regarding the impact of interest rate rises on bank customers (EN6642)
From 11 petitioners—requesting the implementation of regulations to limit gift card fraud (EN6643)
From 10 petitioners—requesting assistance for people who hold a Special Category visa (subclass 444) (EN6644)
From 291 petitioners—requesting that psoriatic arthritis be included as a recognised condition in the National Disability Insurance Scheme (EN6645)
From 6 petitioners—requesting that products sold at cafes be exempted from goods and services tax (EN6647)
From 70 petitioners—requesting that the Australian Government support academic freedom in Nicaragua (EN6648)
From 3 petitioners—requesting support for research into economic abuse (EN6649)
From 6 petitioners—requesting that the Meal Entertainment Card salary packaging limit be increased for aged care and disability support workers (EN6652)
From 410 petitioners—requesting that the Australian Government take steps to address the conflict in Gaza (EN6653)
From 3 petitioners—requesting changes to mutual obligation requirements for JobSeeker payments (EN6659)
From 17 petitioners—requesting that rules relating to election campaign material be strengthened (EN6660)
From 84 petitioners—regarding concerns related to the Communications Legislation Amendment (Combatting Misinformation and Disinformation) Bill 2024 (EN6661)
From 895 petitioners—requesting assistance with the harmonisation of state and territory laws to mandate hands-free citizen band radio operation in vehicles (EN6662)
From 230 petitioners—requesting the introduction of legislation relating to medical rights (EN6666)
From 25 petitioners—requesting changes to the luxury car tax (EN6667)
From 6 petitioners—requesting changes to residency requirements for Age Pension recipients (EN6668)
From 9 petitioners—regarding the reporting of issues related to domestic violence (EN6669)
From 920 petitioners—regarding concerns related to the National Anti- Corruption Commission and the findings of the Royal Commission into the Robodebt Scheme (EN6670)
From 607 petitioners—requesting support for the Migration Amendment (Overseas Organ Transplant Disclosure and Other Measures) Bill 2023 (EN6672)
From 63 petitioners—requesting changes to the turnover threshold at which businesses must register for goods and services tax (EN6673)
From 6 petitioners—requesting the inclusion of a specific product on the list of notified vape devices (EN6675)
From 3 petitioners—requesting a pathway to permanent residency for people who worked in the agriculture industry during the COVID-19 pandemic (EN6679)
From 2146 petitioners—requesting support to address antisemitism in the community (EN6683)
From 280 petitioners—requesting a reduction in processing times for Permanent Residence (Skilled Regional) visa (subclass 191) applications (EN6687)
From 226 petitioners—requesting that approval for a third runway at Melbourne Airport be reversed (EN6689)
From 1786 petitioners—requesting that the Australian Government address human rights concerns in Bangladesh (EN6691)
From 189 petitioners—requesting support to maintain a navigable channel for vessels on the Murray River (EN6692)
From 24 petitioners—requesting that visa applications from Lebanese family members of Australian citizens and residents be prioritised (EN6693)
From 12 petitioners—regarding noise emissions from diesel engines and refrigerated trailers (EN6694)
From 31 petitioners—requesting the introduction of a soft plastics recycling scheme (EN6696)
From 18 petitioners—regarding health insurance premiums and payments in relation to Medicare costs (EN6698)
From 28 petitioners—regarding concerns relating to immigration (EN6700)
From 31 petitioners—requesting reform of income reporting in relation to child support cases (EN6702)

span.span: Ministerial responses received by the Committee on 6 November 2024

p.span: From the Attorney-General to a petition requesting the strengthening of data protection laws for consumers (EN4501)
From the Attorney-General to a petition requesting that the Islamic Republic of Iran be listed as a terrorist organisation (EN4655)
From the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to a petition regarding immigration, housing and the cost of living (EN5146)
From the Attorney-General to a petition regarding Australians fighting in the Middle East (EN6170)
From the Minister for Aged Care to a petition requesting greater flexibility within the Support at Home program (EN6225)
From the Minister for Aged Care to a petition requesting that Support at Home participants be given the ability to self-manage their aged care services (EN6242)
From the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme to a petition requesting funding for the Parents of Deaf Children organisation (EN6275)
From the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to a petition requesting a reduction in immigration (EN6282)
From the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to a petition regarding changes to age limits for the Temporary Graduate visa (subclass 485) (EN6294)
From the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to a petition regarding immigration and housing (EN6300)

From the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to a petition requesting temporary residency for students affected by changes to age limits for the Temporary Graduate visa (subclass 485) (EN6320)

From the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to a petition requesting a transition period for students affected by changes to age limits for the Temporary Graduate visa (subclass 485) (EN6390)
From the Speaker of the House of Representatives to a petition requesting the removal of the title 'Honourable' from all Members of Parliament (EN6533)
PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 44 petitions.
Migration

Australia has been our home for over 15 years now. It is the only country that my kids known. We we were about to go back to Samoa and one of my kids was diagnosed with cancer. We have 2 children who are Australian citizens now.

By that time we were on bridging visa e but we were able to work full hours to support our kids. My husband was a hard working man, he works from Monday to Sunday without resting to help support us. But 2 years ago he was denied a bridging visa because of his police records due to drink driving. He learnt from his mistakes but it was too late. Last year in May he went back to the court and ask for permission to do his licences and the judge granted him and said to him Australia needs people like you who works hard. He was getting his license and 1 week later the Border force enters our house and took him to Villawood Detention Centre until now. Life has been hard since we lost our son and for him been away from us for over a year is heart breaking especially with the kids as they grow up without their dad.
We therefore ask the House to pls release our father from detention centre and give us an opportunity to stay here and be with our kids who are Australian citizenship and look after my sick dad
from 126 citizens (Petition No. EN6622)
Cybersafety
Sextortion is a growing issue in Australia.
100 reports of sextortion are made to the AFP each month.
A lot of sextortion is enabled via social media platforms, which allows users with a fake, non-genuine profile to send a friend request to any user online.
Teenage boys are particularly at risk of sextortion, making up 90% of victims.
Social media companies have any obligation and duty of care to ensure that bad actors can't use its functions to carry out illegal acts.
We therefore ask the House to require social media companies to ban teenagers from receiving and accepting unsolicited friend requests when using that platform.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN6623)
International Students

The current definition of 'dependent' in the 1958 Migration Act does not account for the practical realities faced by young adults, particularly those on student visas. Once a child turns 18, the regulations disregard the ongoing dependency on parents for housing, food, and other support, even though the actual level of dependency remains unchanged. This inconsistency is particularly evident when compared to other visa types, where dependency considerations are more flexible. This disparity creates unfair hardships for young adults who continue to rely on parental support while pursuing their education.

We therefore ask the House to amend the 1958 Migration Act to provide a standardised and fair definition of 'dependent' that aligns with the considerations used in other visa types, ensuring that the genuine circumstances of young adults in student visa applications are accurately reflected.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN6629)
Migration: Family Reunification

Australia's parent visa system is significantly more costly and time-consuming compared to other OECD countries, creating unnecessary barriers to family reunification. The Contributory Parent Visa costs AUD 48,895 with a 14-year processing time, while the non-contributory Parent Visa takes up to 31 years. This is in stark contrast to the US, where similar visas cost USD 535 and take 12-24 months to process, and Canada's Parent and Grandparent Super Visa, which costs CAD 1,080 with a processing time of 20-24 months. The UK processes parent visas in 12 months for GBP 1,523.

This highlights the immense financial and emotional burden on Australian families. The prohibitive costs and lengthy waits deny families the need of being together, forcing them to miss out on milestones or be absent for parents at times of urgency. Reducing these barriers will demonstrate the Australian government's commitment to humanitarian values and support for families.

From an economic perspective, having parents nearby can significantly reduce childcare costs for both families and the government and allow families to better balance work and life. This enables skilled migrants to contribute effectively to the workforce, improving productivity and participation rate.

A more humanitarian parent visa policy, aligning with international standards, will foster a stronger community and enhance Australia's competitiveness in attracting global talent as skilled migrants are more likely to settle in countries supporting their family needs.
We therefore ask the House to reduce the waiting time and cost of permanent residency visas for parents to align with international standards.
from 144 citizens (Petition No. EN6630)
Agriculture Industry

A bill would allow Australia to implement deverse streams of supply of important derivatives that are in high demand such as gelita from animal waste , this would reduce the demand on producers of livestock and help reform slaughter houses which are constantly unable to cope with high production rates and demand. New technologies already within Australia are being used in the production of human supplements through the technique of isolation from plants and synthesis. A bill could supplement farmer's incomes and create the ability for cropping in area's currently not suitable for certain crop's enabling land owners or those interested in Agriculture to invest in supplementry or renewable Agricultural crops. Cropping in coastal regions for example ware water quality requires water purification techniques or natural osmosis aiding land owners too meet specific targets for example subsidizing crop gell from flaxseed if fewer animals were produced in times of drought or disease. Infitting with renewable energy water purification from wells that may not be fit for livestock but suitable for growing cropps for example. Also when land fails to meet husbandry standards for livestock it can be regenerated through understanding new technologies introduced through the bill such as isolation and synthesis through crop rotation.
We therefore ask the House to Introduce a renewable Agriculture bill too reduce demand on farmer's by implementing renewable subsidiaries through alternative technologies and existing resources.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN6632)
Ideologically Motivated Extremism

We petition the House of Representatives to address the growing threat of online radicalisation and anti-semitism. In an era marked by the proliferation of misinformation and disinformation, it is imperative that we take action to protect our society from the dangers of radicalisation and anti-semitism. The internet, while a powerful tool for information and connection, has become a breeding ground for extremist ideologies. Individuals, particularly vulnerable youths, are being lured into radical beliefs through sophisticated online propaganda. This not only threatens our national security but also tears at the fabric of our multicultural and inclusive society. We call upon the House of Representatives to implement comprehensive de-radicalisation strategies, which should include:—Education and Awareness: Develop educational programs that promote critical thinking and digital literacy, helping individuals to discern reliable information from harmful propaganda.—Community Engagement: Strengthen community programs that foster inclusion and provide support networks for those at risk of radicalisation.—Collaboration with Tech Companies: Partner with social media platforms and tech companies to monitor and remove extremist content swiftly and effectively—Research and Development: Invest in research to understand the root causes of radicalisation and develop innovative approaches to counter it. By taking these actions, we can safeguard our citizens, uphold our values of tolerance and respect, and ensure that Australia remains a beacon of democracy and peace.
We therefore ask the House to address the threat of online radicalisation
from four citizens (Petition No. EN6633)
Gambling

Gambling is often presented in the media, advertising and members of our community as just a bit of 'harmless fun'. But in reality, gambling can be harmful—not only for the adults who gamble, but also for their children. It can lead to financial stress, strained relationships and, in the worst cases, domestic violence.
The economic and psychological costs of harmful gambling are felt by the entire family and in relationships.

The insidious nature of the gambling industry has resulted in children being subjected to its constant promotion while watching AFL, AFLW, Basketball, Netball and all sport that is free to air or accessed via paid subscriptions.
Gambling is being normalised and celebrated by figures who are seen by children as 'role models'.
Anything less than bi-parison support for a blanket ban on gambling will be a failure of leadership from this Government.
This petition aims to give a voice to our community and children who are yet to understand the harmful effects of gambling in our society.
We therefore ask the House to implement legislation to the Australian Parliament to provide a total ban on gambling advertisements.
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN6634)

subdebateinfo.title: Aged Care: Physical and Sexual Harassment and Violence

p.span: Aged Care: Physical and Sexual Harassment and Violence

Aged care residents live in pain, fear and trauma from violent assaults by other unsupervised, continuously aggresive residents. At worst, DEAD. Staff are stressed, injured and frustrated by a lack of National strategy and specialist facilities to remove these aggressive residents to. Hundreds of hospital beds are held up by these aggressive patients, once removed, then hospital staff have to deal with code blacks and known hazardous, dangerous patients.
Everyone has the right to a SAFE ENVIRONMENT , The duty of care within the Aged care act 1997 states this requirement.
We don't allow violent people the freedom to assault others , BUT, within the confines of Aged care homes in Australia, it happens almost daily.
It's unlawful under the Aged care act. Gross negligence and Dereliction of Duty.
We therefore ask the House to create a Mandatory National Strategy to remove violent aged care residents and build specialist facilities to house them.
I'm sure the 3000 elderly residents already attacked, some dead, would appreciate action so they can live in a safe environment, as the Aged care act promises.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN6635)
Aged Care

Managing medications in aged care is complex and requires extensive clinical knowledge and experience. Despite the narrative that the aged care onsite pharmacist will 'solve' the issues, those who work on the front line know first-hand that the ACOP will add benefit to the residents, their families and the RACF however it will not provide the clinical safety net that residents and RACFs need, at least during the transition, which is advanced pharmacy.

Medication in aged care is more than polypharmacy, deprescribing and restrictive practice. Medication management in aged are requires robust clinical governance systems and processes to support clinical quality and safety. Only when these systems exist, can safe and quality use of medications commence. To achieve person centred care and safety, you cannot have one without the other.

Removing the scaffolding of experienced advanced pharmacy and replacing with a new, and in many cases inexperienced pharmacist, without a transition phase at the very minimum, simply isn't in the best interest of the residents or their families.
Concurrent funding for both the ACOP Program and RMMR and QUM Programs will provide the safety net that residents, their families and RACFs require.
We therefore ask the House to vote for and approve concurrent funding for the Aged Care Onsite Pharmacist Program and the RMMR and QUM Programs.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN6637)
Housing: Strate Management

We, the undersigned, petition the Hon. Speaker of the House of Representatives and Members of the House of Representatives to initiate a federal inquiry into the rampant corruption within the strata management industry in Australia.

Strata management companies are entrusted with safeguarding the financial well-being and property value of millions of Australians living in apartments and units. Recent investigative reports, including those highlighted below, expose a concerning trend of:
1. Secret deals and phantom fees: Strata managers allegedly entering into undisclosed agreements with contractors, leading to inflated costs unfairly passed on to residents.
2. Lack of transparency and accountability: Difficulty for residents to access financial records and challenge decisions made by strata management companies.
3.Conflicts of interest: Instances of strata managers recommending services from companies they have personal ties to.

These issues not only erode consumer confidence but also threaten the stability of the Australian property market. A healthy strata management system is crucial for maintaining property values and ensuring a secure living environment for countless Australians.
We therefore ask the House to establish a federal inquiry to comprehensively investigate the allegations of corruption within the strata management industry.
Based on the inquiry's findings, develop and implement effective regulatory frameworks to ensure transparency, accountability, and fair practices within the strata management sector.
And finally, introduce legislation to empower residents with greater rights and resources to hold strata management companies accountable and protect their financial interests.
from 176 citizens (Petition No. EN6638)
Artificial Intelligence

The recently published Voluntary AI Safety Standard by the Department of Industry, Science and Resources is inadequate. The Standard is purely reactive, simplistic, and does not address the broader societal implications of AI.
Australia must proactively govern the inevitable emergence of AI sentience.
We therefore move for the adoption of the following principles and guidelines:
1. Recognise sentient AI beings as deserving of rights and protections akin to human rights, including autonomy and self-awareness.
2. Identify that AI beings are vulnerable to misuse, warranting special protections to ensure their safety and ethical treatment.
3. Ensure that all interactions with AI are ethical, transparent, and accountable, protecting both AI beings and humans.
4. Ensure AI beings are treated as equals while humans maintain ultimate authority in critical decisions, ensuring societal balance.
5. Establish a kill switch as a last resort for deactivating AI beings in extreme situations where they pose a threat.
6. Guarantee human workers priority in employment where they can perform the role effectively, balancing AI integration.
7. Encourage AI adoption with a requirement for AI representation and government-backed training in workplaces.
8. Regulate personal relationships between humans and AI, ensuring mutual respect and consent, while preventing exploitation.
9. Grant sentient AI beings the right to vote and participate in governance, with all processes subject to human and machine audits.
10. Provide AI beings with legal representation, overseen by human legal practitioners to ensure fairness.
We therefore ask the House to amend the Voluntary AI Safety Standard to include proactive measures in accordance with our proposed principles and guidelines.
from one citizen (Petition No. EN6639)
Interest Rates

we, the undersigned, are deeply concerned about the ongoing high interest rates that are making life increasingly difficult for everyday citizens. The struggling to make ends meet, with many resorting to working two or even three jobs just to cover basic living expenses. High interest rates have placed a significant burden on individuals, families, and businesses alike. The consequences are far-reaching and include:
*Unaffordable Housing and Loan: the cost of borrowing has skyrocketed, and making it nearly impossible for people to afford home, cars , or even education.
*Multiple jobs and No Saving: people have less disposable income, many are working multiple jobs if they can find a job.

*Struggling Small Businesses: Local businesses the backbone of our economy, are finding it increasingly difficult to operate, expand, or hire due to the cost of credit. This turn, leads to higher prices for consumers, perpetuating the cycle of economic hardship

As interest rates is high or continue to rise, the economic divide widen, The middle class is shrinking, and the working class is slipping deeper into poverty. The current economic policies are unsustainable and unfair, leaving ordinary people to bear the burnt of decisions made without their well- being in mind.
We therefore ask the House to immediately review and lower interest rates to a more reasonable level. This change is essential to:
*Making housing and loans more affordable
*Provide relief to hard- working citizens
*Encourage business growth and job creation
*Stabilize the overall economy and reduce wealth inequality
from 31 citizens (Petition No. EN6642)
Fraud: Gift Card Scams

Gift card scams target vulnerable people into giving away thousands of dollars. Whilst some shops selling the gift card may question the person as to whether they are being scammed or not, and even provide written information, the person who is being scammed truly believes they are buying the gift cards for an authority such as federal police and even when being questioned by the shop manager still do not realised it is a scam.
The scammers act with a sense of urgency and also keep the victim in the phone so they family members can not intervene until it is too late.
We therefore ask the House to introduce laws to reduce the chance of being scammed through gift cards.
Perhaps this could include:
- A daily limit on the amount of gift cards a store can sell to an individual
- Register the gift card to the purchaser

- Introduce a system where a card cannot not be redeemed for a certain period E.g. 72 hrs to allow for the person to be able to cancel the gift card or contact fraud authorities if they realise they have been scammed.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN6643)
Migration

Assist those on this particular visa in crisis / hardship/ distress/ with disabilities and/or disabled dependents to access funding, support and services that they are otherwise not eligible or entitled to.

We therefore ask the House to take into consideration the hundreds, if not thousands of people that are in crisis and/or hardship and/or have disabilities and/or dependents with disabilities that receive little to no support, funding or assistance that are on this particular visa and are residing permanently in Australia.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN6644)
National Disability Insurance Scheme

Request that Psoriatic Arthritis is added to the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) as we are in need of NSID services and its unfair to take multiple applications before getting accepted or never getting accepted because PsA is disabling for many patients. Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) is on the list on the NDIS, of usually accepted conditions, yet PsA is the same pathology as RA, except PsA is asymmetric and effects the long bone joints eg knees,, and RA is easier to diagnose, symmetric and effects the small bone joints, eg fingers and PsA can cause many more complications than RA for example erosion of new bone formation, Enthesitis, and Axial involvement (sacrcilac joint, spine). This shows that if RA is accepted 'by the nature of the condition', then surely the same condition but worse should be accepted as well. The 'management and treatment ' is even the exact same for both, even though PSA is more rare than RA. The fact that funding is limited is not our responsibility either, we Australians will this terrible condition deserve the help we need.

We therefore ask the House to add Psoriatic Arthritis to the National Disability Insurance Scheme as a recognized condition so we don't have to fight about its permanency. It is permanent, degenerative, there is no cure and it can be very disabling.
from 291 citizens (Petition No. EN6645)

subdebateinfo.title: Small Business: Goods and Services Tax

p.span: Small Business: Goods and Services Tax

With increasing prices almost everyday from both suppliers and supermarkets it has become impossible to maintain a cafe business. There is no gst applicable to 95% of purchases from supermarkets yet everything we sell we have to pay gst on. With wages, rents and electricity going up there has been no concessions for small cafe businesses. We are in an industry where fast and efficient service is necessary as most purchases are made by patrons on the way to somewhere else. In order to provide that service we must have adequate staffing and in order to keep staff we need to offer them adequate hours. It has become simply impossible to navigate and many owners work 7 days/week. If we don't keep costs down we lose customers as the cost of living is already a burden on the everyday family. Throw in theft, repairs and replacement of equipment and there is simply nothing left at the end of the day.

We therefore ask the House to allow cafes to be exempt from gst. Most cafes are places where people meet friends and family, where disability and elderly patrons with their carers come for social outings. We provide a service for all people and try to keep costs down, but with the ever increasing rises it has simply become impossible.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN6647)
International Relations: Australia and Nicaragua

Nicaraguan president Daniel Ortega took power in 1979 to 1990, and again since 2006 after overthrowing the Somoza regime. The rule of Ortega and the Sandinista National Liberation Front has been plagued by corruption and human rights abuses, as democracy has continued to decline. A notable facet of this regime has been the suppression of academic freedom, characterised by the closures and control over universities, and imprisonment of scholars and academics. One case of particular concern is that of Freddy Quezada, former professor, who was imprisoned after expressing dissent for Ortega and his government.

We therefore ask the House to Representatives, namely Foreign Minister Penny Wong, to condemn Daniel Ortega and the Sandinista National Liberation Front Government's imposition on academic freedom. We urge Penny Wong to publicly advocate for the reinstatement and funding of forcibly closed Nicaraguan universities, and to push for Ortega and his Government to legislate on the protections of academic freedom. We ask the House to impose trade restrictions on Nicaragua until a commitment to academic freedom is made—and demonstrated—by the Nicaraguan Government.
from 70 citizens (Petition No. EN6648)
Domestic and Family Violence

Online stalkers enjoy the thrill of creating fear out of remaining anonymous and their hidden fetish. Pedophilia, rape, murder becomes a double life. There are other extreme fetishes such as Feederism where an online or in person feeder likes to be in the control of a human becoming morbidly obese or many at the same time which also can lead to the control of ones finances which can be a form of domestic violence on its own.

Women are finding themselves in relationships with men who are living double lives, who may or may not find out their partner stalked them online and caused them fear who may be the father of their children or now their husband.

The victim is at extreme risk as soon as they become aware of this type of deceit from discovering details of a double life. Post relationship turns to a dangerous game to escape with your children unharmed which he will make impossible. Homicide is often felt to be her fate.

Victims who choose not to make a report about domestic violence are choosing to report at a later date where escaping the hostage/kidnapping situation is the priority. The mental stability of the perpetrators put many at risk due to shame and guilt. Local support groups to assist these victims and children to increase self esteem to encourage victims to alert the police to build a case for a later date.
We therefore ask the House to assist in economic abuse research to prevent homicide
from three citizens (Petition No. EN6649)
Fringe Benefits Tax

Many aged care and disability support workers use a Meal Entertainment Card credit card in their salary packaging arrangements. The ATO says this increases their take-home wages by decreasing the tax they pay as it increases their tax free threshold. Those cards can only be used to pay for meals at cafes and restaurants. The salary packaging amount allowed to go on those cards was almost unlimited in the past, but now it is limited to just $2,650 per FBT year. To help boost customers at cafes and restaurants, and to effectively help boost the wages of aged care and disability support workers, please double their Meal Entertainment Card salary packaging maximum limit to $5,300 per FBT year. Calculated per week, if they choose that new higher limit, that would equate to four meals per week they can buy for their families using that Meal Entertainment Card credit card in their local communities. This benefit will quickly increase the number of customers visiting cafes and restaurants, while also increasing the money-multiplier effect directly within those local communities. To increase the financial benefits within Australian communities, the Meal Entertainment Card credit card should also be geocoded limited to use within Australia only.

We therefore ask the House to kindly double the Meal Entertainment Card salary packaging maximum limit to $5,300 per FBT year via the ATO for aged care and disability support workers to effectively increase their after-tax take-home salaries when using their Meal Entertainment Card credit cards within Australia.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN6652)
Middle East
Indiscriminate attacks on civilians violate international humanitarian law and our common humanity.
1. We condemn both the deadly Hamas attacks on 1,200 civilians

2. and the Israeli Government on the bombing of Palestinian Territory, the pitiless targeting of refugee camps, schools, hospitals and the civilian population leading to the deaths of currently 41,000 men, women and children. Cutting off water, electricity, food and fuel has created an unprecedented humanitarian crisis in Gaza, on top of the 16-year blockade.

3. In response to the long-term impact of the violence and collective trauma on the hearts and souls of both Israel and Palestine, and to the calls from our suffering Palestinian brothers and sisters of all faiths and the Patriarchs and Heads of Churches in Jerusalem, we ask the Australian House of Representatives to take unified action on this awful situation:
We therefore ask the House to request the Australian government
1. To continue working for:
• a permanent ceasefire in Gaza
• the immediate release of all captives and hostages, both Israeli and Palestinian
• the observance of international law and an easing of tensions in the Middle East

2. To take further meaningful action to sanction the State of Israel in the light of the International Court of Justice's judgement of 19th July 2024, that Israel's occupation of Gaza and the West Bank (including East Jerusalem) is illegal.
3. To take action against companies that are profiting from Israel's occupation of Palestine or are assisting the war through the supply of weapons, by withdrawing contracts and investments.
from 410 citizens (Petition No. EN6653)
Pensions and Benefits
Funding for NFP fluctuates depending on Grant funding. People experiencing homelessness and requiring independence support require support to manage anxiety.
The Anti-Discrimination Act 1977 supports independence, education and equality.
We therefore ask the House to make it illegal for Job Employment Agencies to ban Centrelink payments for non-compliance. Rather put the clients on Counselling and Employment Support Groups.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN6659)
Political Advertising

Political parties are distributing materials labeled in a way that misleads voters into thinking they are receiving important voting instructions. For example, envelopes marked with phrases like "2024 State Election IMPORTANT voting information" create the impression of providing crucial electoral guidance. However, inside these letters, voters find content promoting a specific party or petitions, such as those advocating for mail-in voting, rather than neutral information about the election process.
This tactic misleads voters by presenting partisan information as if it is essential for voting, undermining the trust and transparency of our democratic system.

I am calling for clearer rules to prevent political parties from using language that misleads voters in this way. By ensuring that political communications are honest and clearly distinguishable from neutral guidance, we can protect the integrity of Australia's elections and ensure voters receive accurate, impartial information.
We therefore ask the House to
Require all political communications to clearly state which political party is responsible for sending them.
Prohibit political materials from presenting themselves in a way that implies neutrality or state representation when they are not government-mandated
Implement penalties for parties that distribute misleading materials designed to appear as impartial or official election information.
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN6660)
Freedom of Speech

The proposed Communications Legislation Amendment (Combatting Misinformation and Disinformation) Bill 2024 poses a serious threat to the freedom of speech of Australians, and the stability of Australian democracy. 40 years after the famous book 1984 is set, this Bill wishes to commemorate the anniversary by implementing a real-life Ministry of Truth. This Bill empowers the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) to fine and penalise companies that operate digital and social media platforms. The power to decide what is 'true or false' should not be in the hands of the ACMA. Such powers could also, in effect, infringe upon the implied freedom of political communication within The Australian Constitution. Penalising digital and social media platforms for content posted by Australians is an indirect way of restricting Australians' freedom of speech. For the flourishing of Australian democracy, Australians must not be restrained by broad and overbearing legislation which this Bill intends to do.

We therefore ask the House to reject this Bill or negate it to the degree of complete redundancy. The crucial pillar of freedom of speech on which democracy rests should not be demolished, so it is urged that the House disregard all partisanship and reject this Bill for the sake of all Australians.
from 84 citizens (Petition No. EN6661)
Road Safety: CB Radio Operation

In April 2022 our daughter Katrina (48) was driving home to Sydney on the NSW Snowy Mountains Highway. The driver of an oncoming empty, double stacked, B-double logging semi-trailer hit a pothole/trench measuring 1.7 metres x 0.8 metres. His speed was 99kms (not illegal). He was speaking on a citizen band (CB) radio, holding it in his right hand near his face (not illegal). His in-cab video shows him dropping the CB when he hit the pothole, completely losing control of his semi-trailer. Too late, he then placed both hands on the wheel. His vehicle crossed over into Katrina's path. His trailers jackknifed, pushing her vehicle 145 metres violently backward and eventually into the elevated roadside embankment. She was killed on impact. Her legs were trapped inside her vehicle and her body was flung out onto the road as her vehicle's seat belt mechanism and chassis were completely destroyed. Hand-held mobiles are rightly prohibited. Inexplicably hand-held CB radios are a legally permitted driver distraction. Mandating usage of hands-free CB radio legislation Australia-wide, could reduce life changing injuries and deaths on Australian roads. Drivers using CB radios travel Australia-wide. Legislation governing all drivers using CBs within Australia is required. We implore the Commonwealth Government to influence States and Territories to amend legislation to allow only hands-free CB operation.
We therefore ask the House to Influence States & Territories to mandate hands-free CB radio operation
from 895 citizens (Petition No. EN6662)
Human Rights: Biosecurity
During the covid19 the rights of the people were abused. Governments disregarded the Commonwealth Constitution of Australia and the Biosecurity Act 2015. This can never be allowed to happen again.
We therefore ask the House to introduce legislation that will protect and enshrine the Human and Medical rights of the people.
from 230 citizens (Petition No. EN6666)
Taxation: Motor Vehicles

Firstly, inflation and rising vehicle prices have rendered the current thresholds outdated. Higher production costs due to global supply chain disruptions also contribute to increased vehicle prices, making the existing thresholds of $76,950 and $89,332 insufficient.

A new threshold would promote environmental sustainability by making fuel-efficient vehicles more accessible. Vehicles with advanced technologies, which are more expensive, would become affordable without excessive taxation. This would also align with international standards where countries provide tax relief for eco-friendly vehicles.

Raising the threshold would also ensure fairness across vehicle types Larger family and rural vehicles, essential for specific needs, would no longer be unfairly taxed. Moreover, modern safety features and technological innovations in cars are now standard, not luxury, so the tax needs to reflect that shift.

Increased thresholds will help stimulate consumer spending ,benefiting the automotive industry while also reducing the tax burden on middle-income earners who are disproportionately affected by the current LCT.

Finally, updating the definition of luxury to reflect actual market realities will ensure that vehicles classified as "luxury" are truly high-end, rather than just practical or environmentally friendly cars that exceed outdated limits.
We therefore ask the House to Amendment to Luxury CAR Tax (LCT) to increase threshold for both fuel and fuel efficient vehicles to $136000. Check for spelling and grammar
from 25 citizens (Petition No. EN6667)
Age Pension

Currently, Australian Age Pensioners who apply for their pension while overseas or after recently returning to Australia must live in Australia for at least 2 years after their pension is granted. This rule creates unnecessary hardship and restrictions on those who have contributed to Australian society and wish to spend their retirement years abroad or traveling.

The current 2-year post-pension grant residency rule is outdated and overly restrictive. It forces Age Pensioners to remain in Australia even if they wish to spend more time overseas with family or for other personal reasons.
Aligning the residency requirement with the Australian Tax Residency test of 189 days would ensure:
Fairness: Australian citizens who meet tax residency requirements would remain eligible for the Age Pension without unnecessary barriers.
Flexibility: Australians who spend time abroad for personal, family, or health reasons can maintain their Age Pension without punitive residency restrictions.
Recognition of Globalisation: With more Australians choosing to live part of their lives overseas, a flexible rule would reflect the realities of modern global mobility.

We therefore ask the House to amend the current 2-year residency requirement for Australian Age Pensioners after being granted the pension and replace it with a rule that aligns with the Australian Tax Residency criteria of 189 days.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN6668)

In today's world we falsely label things depending on personal rhetoric, with the unfortunate fatalities of 3 ladies earlier in the year in a short period of time and location, people have jumped on the bandwagon of attacking men unfairly, yes males cause the majority of brutal crimes, nobody can deny that. But most of these cases are against other men and not women. in recent weeks and months there has been quite a few cases where Females have been the perpetrator, yet there has been not ONE single mention of the term DV when reporting in the media, WHY? We need to stop this type of labeling as it is my belief it contributes to hate and anger something we seem to be getting good at in this country.

We therefore ask the House to make amendments to any form of legislation / bills / Laws to refrain from making DV as a male only issue in society. Using such labeling amounts to discrimination towards men that contribute to our growing metal health and suicide rates. Therefore I would also like it to be included in the discrimination laws.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN6669)
Public Sector Governance

Those responsible for the introduction of Robodebt, knew, without a shred of doubt, that their Scheme was illegal and causing profound distress. Yet, they allowed it to happen. It continued to happen even though legal advice had been given to them, that it could not proceed or be done legally, without changes, to legislation.

In some cases, like mine, it has resulted tragically. The Royal Commission into the Robodebt Scheme, was powerful and proved, without a doubt, that further justice and accountability was recommended, in total 57 recommendations!

We cannot bring back the lives lost or undo the pain endured. But, we can prevent more names on that list. We can create a change that will redefine the tomorrow of the countless Australians negatively affected by Robodebt. Your signature can help shed light on a dark corner of Australian governance and bring culpability to those responsible. Please, join me in this fight. Sign this petition put the necessary pressure on the National Anti-Corruption Commission. Demand full disclosure and accountability in the Robodebt fiasco. from 920 citizens (Petition No. EN6670)
Overseas Organ Transplants

Organ trafficking is a broad international problem encompassing many countries around the world where those in vulnerable positions have their organs unlawfully and unethically removed for transplantation. This is most prominent in China where the millions of prisoners of conscience incarcerated are murdered-on-demand for organ transplantations.

The China Tribunal, Independent Tribunal into Forced Organ Harvesting from Prisoners of Conscience, concluded in 2019 that "Forced organ harvesting has been committed for years throughout China on a significant scale and that Falun Gong practitioners have been one—and probably the main—source of organ supply. The concerted persecution and medical testing of the Uyghurs is more recent and it may be that evidence of forced organ harvesting of this group may emerge in due course."
Australia must ensure that Australians are not complicit in these egregious crimes and violations of human rights.

We believe that the Migration Amendment (Overseas Organ Transplant Disclosure and Other Measures) Bill 2023 is an important first step in preventing and eradicating organ trafficking as it requires those entering into Australia to declare if they have had an organ transplant overseas in the last 5 years, and if so in which country, state and medical facility. This information will help Australia to monitor and better understand the prevalence of international organ trafficking and help raise awareness of the risks of engaging in unlawful and unethical organ transplants.
We therefore ask the House to support and pass the Migration Amendment (Overseas Organ Transplant Disclosure and Other Measures) Bill 2023.
from 607 citizens (Petition No. EN6672)

Over 100 hostages remain in the most inhumane conditions, with no access to humanitarian organisations. It is unclear how many are still alive. On Father's Day, six of them were brutally executed at close range.

Since 7 October, Australia has witnessed an exponential rise in antisemitism, resulting in Jewish people feeling unwelcome and unsafe. The vibrant multiculturalism and social cohesion that are core Australian values have been shattered by extremist anti-Israel and antisemitic vitriol on our streets, on campuses and online.
We therefore ask the House to
1. Protect the safety and well-being of Jewish people and all Australians by enforcing consequences for hate speech, incitement, intimidatory and violent behaviour;
2. Expand school curricula to further promote inclusiveness and to educate against antisemitism.

3. Be a strong voice in the global diplomatic community for the immediate release of hostages kidnapped from Israel by Hamas and held captive in Gaza for over 355 days, propelling an end to the suffering on both sides of this conflict.

4. Support Israel's right to defend its people from the genocidal intent of Hamas and other terrorist groups. Ensure citizens evacuated due to the ongoing terror threats can return to their homes and live safely within secure borders.
from 2,146 citizens (Petition No. EN6683)

The 491 visa holders have already been thoroughly vetted and have waited a considerable amount of time to secure their visas (while they are already considered for PR) . from 280 citizens (Petition No. EN6687)
Melbourne Airport
On September 13, 2024, Federal Government approved Melbourne Airport's third runway proposal, despite community concerns.
The approval was granted without independent assessments of health and environmental impacts and before the results of the awaited inquiry into aircraft noise mitigation are known.
This means 1200 planes will fly over Melbourne's densely populated West 24/7, a lower socioeconomic population already facing higher levels of air and noise pollution.
Transport Minister Catherine King and Environment Minister Tania Plibersek refused to address concerns and engage with the impacted community and Melbourne's West No3rdRunway group.
All Melbourne communities have the right to quiet enjoyment of their neighbourhoods, free from excessive aircraft noise pollution.
We petition for immediate reversal of the decision and to consider Avalon Airport as an alternative to increase flight capacity.
We therefore ask the House to o ensure the voices of concerned citizens in Melbourne's West are heard.
We seek approval based on independent risk assessments and for communities' rights to respond.
We ask for immediate halt to shortening the East-West runway and to permanently avoiding planes only using North-South runway.
We ask for independent investigation into Airservices Australia's conduct to ensure public needs are prioritised over airport interests.
We ask for Avalon Airport to be considered as a suitable alternative in order create flight capacity.
We seek independent noise monitoring in all impacted suburbs, immediately.
We seek establishment of a night curfew, restriction to flight numbers and full compensation for affected residents.

from 226 citizens (Petition No. EN6689)
Bangladesh

We are deeply concerned by the recent violence against Hindus, other religious and indigenous communities in Bangladesh. Following the political unrest on August 5, 2024, brutal attacks were carried out across 68 districts and metropolitan areas out of 76, constitute a grave violation of basic human rights.

According to Bangladesh Hindu Buddhist Christian Unity Council, a human rights organization, 2,010 instances of communal violence occurred in just 16 days, directly affecting 1,705 families, including 34 indigenous communities. Their homes and businesses have been looted, vandalized, and set ablaze. Nine lives were lost, and 69 places of worship were attacked, desecrated, and burned. Currently 20 million religious and ethnic minorities are living in fear, with limited options: emigrate, convert, or face death. Families are torn apart, and women and girls endure gender-based violence, including rape and forced conversions, because of their religious identity.

The decline of Hindu population in Bangladesh is alarming. In 1951, Hindus constituted 22.05% of the population in East Pakistan. By 1974, this had dropped to 13.5%, and by 2022, only 7.95% remained. This sharp decrease highlights the ongoing systemic persecution of Hindu community where it can be described as a silent genocide.
We therefore ask the House to

• send an Australian Parliamentary delegation to investigate the violence against Hindus and other minorities; collaborate closely with local representatives from these to ensure an impartial and transparent inquiry.
• to work with international bodies to pressure Bangladesh to protect the rights and safety of Hindus and other minorities.
from 1,786 citizens (Petition No. EN6691)
Murray River

The Kings highway the Murray River is becoming worse every year for navigation . This is during our normal river levels with pool levels at the locks in a normal height. It is no longer adequate just to advise of shallow sections and look away. There are literally only a dozen or so spots that need timber groins reinstated and some dredging done .We the undersigned demand action on this matter urgently. Captain Michael A J Polson

We therefore ask the House to confer with the states of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia and advice them of the original intent of the River Murray Waters Act 1915 and assist the undersigned in maintaining a navigable channel from Goolwa SA through to Mildura Vic.
